prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for dumping my gf after her unannounced backpacking trip
Ok so this happened maybe three days ago, but first some context.

Me and my (now ex) girlfriend of 3 years lived in a 2 bedroom apartment which I pay for by myself, as I make enough money to afford it and I didn’t want to trouble her by pressing her with a bill for a place that is a tiny bit out of her price range, instead we use a meter and pay the bill through my account, with her compensating her  spend.
 
We also have always been big on trust since both of us have been cheated on in previous relationships, and didn’t want to go through that again in this one.

The fact that I pay solely this apartment is important as it allows her to spend her money on things like more expensive gifts and the occasional excursion for us (which of course I pay in part for). Also the fact that we are big on trust means we tell eachother A lot about our lives and future plans.

Anyways, she was always a fan of these trips abroad and loved travelling, and for the most part our trips were always fun. However, about three days ago she announced that she had bought tickets for a solo backpacking trip across South America which she was going to go on on Friday, and that she had been planning this for months.

First I asked if I could come, to which she said no because she would be “discovering herself” on this trip, and when I asked why hadn’t she told me she said because I wouldn’t have allowed (or at the very least not wanted) her to go, especially alone.  (Which is mostly true)

Well an argument ensued and at some point I finally put my foot down, it went something like this: 

Gf: “why can’t I just go explore the world and live life to its fullest”

Me: “you can, without me or the security of my home, pack your bags and get out”

I believe it was the right thing to do as she didn’t pay for the apartment anyways, and so didn’t have any right to demand to stay, plus I was willing to give her money for a hotel for a week, which she refused.

That night she went to her parents home an hour away and my phone was blown up with people calling me a controlling asshole and the like, my question is am I really an asshole for this?

TLDR: girlfriend popped a surprise solo trip on me 5 days before she left, saying she wanted to go alone and had been planning it for months, I kicked her out my house. 


"""

I think the author is in the wrong but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see here. The user is asking if the author is in the wrong after breaking up with his girlfriend for going on an unannounced backpacking trip. The context is that they lived in an apartment he paid for, and they had a strong emphasis on trust due to past betrayals.

First, I need to assess the situation from both sides. The author mentions that she had planned the trip for months but didn't tell him. He asked to join, she said no because she wanted to "discover herself." When he found out, he argued and told her to leave the house. She went to her parents, and he got criticized by others.

So, the key points here: communication issues. She didn't inform him about a significant life decision—plans for months. But why? She thought he wouldn't allow it. Maybe she felt he was too controlling. However, in a healthy relationship, major plans should be discussed, especially when they affect the relationship dynamics.

The author's reaction: he kicked her out of the apartment he paid for. Since she didn't pay rent, maybe he felt he had the right. But was it the right thing emotionally? Ending the relationship in that way might be seen as harsh, especially if there's a history of trust issues. The argument led to an immediate breakup, which seems impulsive. Maybe he should have tried to talk through it instead of using the breakup as a reaction.

The fact that they had a history of valuing trust suggests that open communication was important. Her not sharing the trip could have been a breach of that trust. But the author's response was extreme. Telling her to leave during an argument might have been a power move, which could be seen as controlling, even if he's the one paying for the apartment. 

Also, the fact that she was going solo and he felt it was a problem might indicate underlying issues about trust and control. If they both were against cheating before, maybe this was a different kind of trust issue. But the author's method of ending things is questionable. Instead of addressing the issue, he escalated it to a breakup, which might have been a knee-jerk reaction.

So, considering all that, the author might be in the wrong for not handling the situation more maturely. Even if he felt betrayed, the way he ended the relationship could be seen as harsh and possibly controlling. Therefore, the answer might be A, he is in the wrong.
